flags: Unable to speak, or able to speak only single words
Silent chest, cyanosis, poor respiratory effort

children.text: Take a brief history and perform rapid examination.
Decide if asthma is the most likely diagnosis. Consider:
causes episodic wheezing and shortness of breath that responds reliably to bronchodilator treatment.
is rarely diagnosed unless there have been at least 2 to 3 episodes. However, in some cases it may be the only likely diagnosis even on the first episode.
is rare, but not excluded, in children younger than 1 year.

is the main cause of episodic wheeze in infants and should not be treated with a bronchodilator. If the following risk factors are present, consider whether a trial of asthma treatment is appropriate:
is accompanied by objective signs of wheezing, increased work of breathing, and hyperexpansion of the chest.
usually responds (by decreased work of breathing) to inhaled bronchodilator treatment, whereas few other conditions do so.
Cough is common in asthma, but is very rarely the sole symptom and is not specific for asthma. See
A history of interval symptoms, particularly wheeze in response to exercise, cold air, or specific allergens, makes asthma likely.
A family history of asthma, and atopic disease in the child (e.g. atopic eczema, hay fever, positive skin prick tests to inhaled allergens) increase the likelihood that wheezing is due to asthma.
. A viral infection occurring in children younger than 12 months. Usually associated with fine inspiratory crackles, as well as wheeze.
Recurrent virus-triggered episodes of wheeze in children with no risk factors for asthma, except smoking exposure in pregnancy.
Usually does not persist past age 3 years.
Hyperventilation. Increased rate and work of breathing, but with excellent chest expansion and air entry, and no wheeze.
Wheeze, cough, and/or shortness of breath, of abrupt onset usually associated with a choking episode (sometimes this is not observed).
Wheeze may be unilateral and monophonic but not always.
. Sudden onset, usually associated with rash, angio-oedema, and sometimes with stridor.
Sometimes reported by parents as wheeze but is a predominantly inspiratory monophonic sound.
Causes include croup and upper airway disorders.
Laryngeal disorders associated with symptoms of cough, choking, and difficulty breathing, particularly during competitive exercise in older children and teenagers.
Aspiration syndromes. Usually associated with swallowing disorders, e.g. with low tone, developmental delay, neuromuscular disorders, or congenital oesophageal disorders.
Include bronchogenic cysts compressing airway, other masses, or vascular rings compressing airway, tracheomalacia, or bronchomalacia.
Usually manifest by constant or highly predictable wheezing and/or cough.
Usually do not present with acute respiratory distress.
Silent chest, exhaustion, cyanosis, increasing hypoxia
Unable to speak or able to speak only single words
If present, proceed to Management immediately.
– mild, moderate, or severe. Wheeze is not a good indicator of severity. If moderate or severe, measure oxygen saturation.
Give a single treatment dose of salbutamol metered-dose inhaler (MDI) via spacer.
If not responding, manage as moderate.
educate the parents or caregivers about
and further management, and provide an Asthma Action Plan.
1 mg/kg (maximum 40 mg) as an immediate dose, however not all children need this.
If in a non-urban location, consider phoning the on-call paediatrician on
about resuscitation and stabilisation and the mode of transport.
a history of respiratory arrest or life-threatening asthma.
social factors, such as access to transport and phone, parental coping.
Measure oxygen saturation and give oxygen if SaO2 is less than 92%.
If no sustained relief from a single treatment dose of salbutamol metered-dose inhaler (MDI) via spacer after 20 minutes:
repeat the same dose of salbutamol MDI via spacer every 20 minutes to complete an hour of treatment (3 spacers within 60 minutes), commonly called blast therapy.
be aware that using a nebuliser is no more effective than using an MDI via a spacer.
1 mg/kg immediately. During recovery, the same dose is given daily for up to 3 days.
Reassess regularly. If moderate asthma is not responding after 3 salbutamol treatment doses 20 minutes apart, manage as severe asthma.
After 1 hour, if the child has improved, consider if they can be managed at home:
Observe for at least 1 hour after the last dose of medication.
Educate the parents or caregivers about
and further management, and provide an Asthma Action Plan.
If in a non-urban location, consider phoning the on-call paediatrician on
about resuscitation and stabilisation and the mode of transport to hospital.
not clearly improving after 1 hour of treatment.
call an ambulance, stating priority 1 and advanced paramedic required.
seek advice from the on-call paediatrician on
about resuscitation, stabilisation, and the mode of transport to hospital.
seek advice from the on-call paediatrician on
about resuscitation, stabilisation, and the mode of transport to hospital.
and arrange ambulance transport to hospital.
and arrange ambulance transport to hospital if moderate asthma and:
not clearly improving after 1 hour of treatment.
history of respiratory arrest or life-threatening asthma.
social factors, such as access to transport and phone, parental coping.
If mild or moderate asthma and in a non-urban location, consider phoning the on-call paediatrician on
about resuscitation and stabilisation and the mode of transport to hospital.
